message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Credibility assessment of in silico clinical trials for medical devices
Paper Abstract: In silico clinical trials (ISCTs) are an emerging method in modeling and simulation where medical interventions are evaluated using computational models of patients. ISCTs have the potential to provide cost-effective, time-efficient, and ethically favorable alternatives for evaluating the safety and effectiveness of medical devices. However, ensuring the credibility of ISCT results is a significant challenge. This paper aims to identify unique considerations for assessing the credibility of ISCTs and proposes an ISCT credibility assessment workflow based on recently published model assessment frameworks. First, we review various ISCTs described in the literature, carefully selected to showcase the range of methodological options available. These studies cover a wide variety of devices, reasons for conducting ISCTs, patient model generation approaches including subject-specific versus ‘synthetic’ virtual patients, complexity levels of devices and patient models, incorporation of clinician or clinical outcome models, and methods for integrating ISCT results with real-world clinical trials. We next discuss how verification, validation, and uncertainty quantification apply to ISCTs, considering the range of ISCT approaches identified. Based on our analysis, we then present a hierarchical workflow for assessing ISCT credibility, using a general credibility assessment framework recently published by the FDA’s Center for Devices and Radiological Health. Overall, this work aims to promote standardization in ISCTs and contribute to the wider adoption and acceptance of ISCTs as a reliable tool for evaluating medical devices.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Uncertainty quantification"

Links: [{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Quantification of margins and uncertainties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantification_of_margins_and_uncertainties"},{"title":"Talk:Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Uncertainty analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_analysis"},{"title":"Talk:Numerical methods for partial differential equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Numerical_partial_differential_equations"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Climate change/Figures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Climate_change/Figures"},{"title":"Talk:Info-gap decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Info-gap_decision_theory"},{"title":"Oil and gas reserves and resource quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingent_resources"},{"title":"Integrated Carbon Observation System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Carbon_Observation_System"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about uncertainty quantification:

## Definition

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications.(no content)It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

## Types of Uncertainty

The field distinguishes between two main types of uncertainty:

- **Aleatoric Uncertainty**: Uncertainty characterized by inherent randomness which cannot be reduced by further data is called aleatory uncertainty.

- **Epistemic Uncertainty**: Epistemic uncertainty represents a lack of knowledge about the appropriate value to use for a quantity and is sometimes referred to as state of knowledge uncertainty, subjective uncertainty, Type B, or reducible uncertainty, meaning that the uncertainty can be reduced through increased understanding (research), or increased and more relevant data.

## Major Problem Areas

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sources of uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

## Applications

Uncertainty quantification intends to explicitly express both types of uncertainty separately. This is particularly important in engineering design and computational modeling, where understanding and quantifying uncertainties is critical for making robust system design decisions.

Here are the search results for "Medical device":

## Definition
A medical device is any device intended to be used for medical purposes.

## Range and Examples
Examples range from simple, low-risk devices such as tongue depressors, medical thermometers, disposable gloves, and bedpans to complex, high-risk devices that are implanted and sustain life, including artificial hearts, pacemakers, joint replacements, and CT scans.

## Safety and Regulation
Medical devices must be proved safe and effective with reasonable assurance before regulating governments allow marketing of the device in their country, and as the associated risk of the device increases the amount of testing required to establish safety and efficacy also increases.

## Market Size
The global medical device market was estimated to be between $220 and US$250 billion in 2013, with the United States controlling approximately 40% of the global market followed by Europe (25%), Japan (15%), and the rest of the world (20%).

## Regulatory History
In the United States, the Medical Device Amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act in 1976 established medical device regulation as we know it today, while in Europe, the Medical Device Directive came into effect in 1993 and the Medical Device Regulation replaced it on May 26, 2017.

Web search results for query: "Verification validation"

Links: [{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Informal methods of validation and verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informal_methods_of_validation_and_verification"},{"title":"Katherine Johnson Independent Verification and Validation Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine_Johnson_Independent_Verification_and_Validation_Facility"},{"title":"Verification and validation of computer simulation models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation_of_computer_simulation_models"},{"title":"Software verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Validation and verification (medical devices) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validation_and_verification_(medical_devices)"},{"title":"Talk:Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Verification_and_Validation"},{"title":"Verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification"},{"title":"Data validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_validation"},{"title":"Telephone number verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telephone_number_verification"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of verification and validation:

## Overview

Verification and validation (also abbreviated as V&V) are independent procedures that are used together for checking that a product, service, or system meets requirements and specifications and that it fulfills its intended purpose.

## Key Differences

While related, verification and validation serve distinct purposes:

- **Verification**: Verification is intended to check that a product, service, or system meets a set of design specifications. In simple terms, software verification ensures that "you built it right" and confirms that the product, as provided, fulfills the plans of the developers.

- **Validation**: Validation is intended to ensure a product, service, or system (or portion thereof, or set thereof) results in a product, service, or system (or portion thereof, or set thereof) that meets the operational needs of the user. Put another way, software validation ensures that "you built the right thing" and confirms that the product, as provided, fulfills the intended use and goals of the stakeholders.

## Important Distinction

It is entirely possible that a product passes when verified but fails when validated. This can happen when, say, a product is built as per the specifications but the specifications themselves fail to address the user's needs.

The concepts of verification and validation apply across various domains including software engineering, medical devices, computer simulation models, and quality management systems.

Put another way, software validation ensures that "you built the right thing" and confirms that the product, as provided, fulfills the intended use and goals of the stakeholders.

## Important Distinction

It is entirely possible that a product passes when verified but fails when validated. This can happen when, say, a product is built as per the specifications but the specifications themselves fail to address the user's needs.

The concepts of verification and validation apply across various domains including software engineering, medical devices, computer simulation models, and quality management systems.

I've completed the web search for "Patient model." The results provide information about several healthcare-related models and concepts:

## Key Findings:

**Different Types of Patient Models:**

1. **Medical Model** - An important aspect of the medical model is that it regards signs (objective indicators such as an elevated temperature) and symptoms (subjective feelings of distress expressed by the patient) as indicative of an underlying physical abnormality (pathology) within the individual.

2. **Simulated/Standardized Patient** - In health care, a simulated patient (SP), also known as a standardized patient, sample patient, or patient instructor, is an individual trained to act as a real patient in order to simulate a set of symptoms or problems.

3. **Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX)** - Patient derived xenografts (PDX) are models of cancer where the tissue or cells from a patient's tumor are implanted into an immunodeficient or humanized mouse.

4. **Patient-Centered Outcomes** - Patient-centered outcomes focus attention on a patient's beliefs, opinions, and needs in conjunction with a physician's medical expertise and assessment.

5. **Synergy Model of Nursing** - The core concept underlying the synergy model is nurse-patient interaction as reciprocal and constantly evolving while each party responds to the characteristics and actions of the other. Synergy, or ideal patient outcomes, can be reached by matching patient needs and characteristics with appropriate nurse competencies.

The search results cover various interpretations of "patient model" across healthcare education, research, and clinical practice.

I've performed a web search for "Computer simulation." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Purpose

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.(no content)By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.

## Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics, astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## History

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Types of Simulations

Applications include flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits. Additionally, simulation is used in many contexts, such as simulation of technology for performance tuning or optimizing, safety engineering, testing, training, education, and video games.

Web search results for query: "In silico"

Links: [{"title":"In silico - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico"},{"title":"In silico (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"In Silico (Pendulum album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_Silico_(Pendulum_album)"},{"title":"Talk:In silico - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:In_silico"},{"title":"Everyone in Silico - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everyone_in_Silico"},{"title":"In silico Plants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_Plants"},{"title":"In silico medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_medicine"},{"title":"Insilico Medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insilico_Medicine"},{"title":"In silico clinical trials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_clinical_trials"},{"title":"In Silico (Deepsky album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_Silico_(Deepsky_album)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what "in silico" means:

## Definition

In biology and other experimental sciences, an in silico experiment is one performed on a computer or via computer simulation software.(no content)The phrase is pseudo-Latin for 'in silicon' (correct Latin: in silicio), referring to silicon in computer chips.

## Origin and History

It was coined in 1987 as an allusion to the Latin phrases in vivo, in vitro, and in situ, which are commonly used in biology (especially systems biology).(no content)The earliest known use of the phrase was by Christopher Langton to describe artificial life, in the announcement of a workshop on that subject at the Center for Nonlinear Studies at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in 1987.

## Applications

In silico methods have diverse applications across different fields:

- **Medicine and Drug Discovery**: In silico study in medicine is thought to have the potential to speed the rate of discovery while reducing the need for expensive lab work and clinical trials. One way to achieve this is by producing and screening drug candidates more effectively.

- **Clinical Trials**: An in silico clinical trial, also known as a virtual clinical trial, is an individualized computer simulation used in the development or regulatory evaluation of a medicinal product, device, or intervention.

- **Computational Medicine**: In silico medicine (also known as "computational medicine") is the application of in silico research to problems involving health and medicine. It is the direct use of computer simulation in the diagnosis, treatment, or prevention of a disease.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- **Clinical Trials**: An in silico clinical trial, also known as a virtual clinical trial, is an individualized computer simulation used in the development or regulatory evaluation of a medicinal product, device, or intervention.

- **Computational Medicine**: In silico medicine (also known as "computational medicine") is the application of in silico research to problems involving health and medicine. It is the direct use of computer simulation in the diagnosis, treatment, or prevention of a disease.

## Definition

In biology and other experimental sciences, an in silico experiment is one performed on a computer or via computer simulation software.(no content)The phrase is pseudo-Latin for 'in silicon' (correct Latin: in silicio), referring to silicon in computer chips.

## Origin and History

It was coined in 1987 as an allusion to the Latin phrases in vivo, in vitro, and in situ, which are commonly used in biology (especially systems biology).(no content)The earliest known use of the phrase was by Christopher Langton to describe artificial life, in the announcement of a workshop on that subject at the Center for Nonlinear Studies at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in 1987.

In silico methods have diverse applications across different fields:

- **Medicine and Drug Discovery**: In silico study in medicine is thought to have the potential to speed the rate of discovery while reducing the need for expensive lab work and clinical trials. One way to achieve this is by producing and screening drug candidates more effectively.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about clinical trials:

## Definition

Clinical trials are prospective biomedical or behavioral research studies on human participants designed to answer specific questions about biomedical or behavioral interventions, including new treatments such as novel vaccines, drugs, dietary choices, dietary supplements, and medical devices.

## Purpose and Goals

Clinical trials generate data on dosage, safety and efficacy. More specifically, there are two goals to testing medical treatments: to learn whether they work well enough, called "efficacy", or "effectiveness"; and to learn whether they are safe enough, called "safety".

## Trial Phases

Clinical trials testing potential medical products are commonly classified into four phases. The drug development process will normally proceed through all four phases over many years.(no content)If the drug successfully passes through Phases I, II, and III, it will usually be approved by the national regulatory authority for use in the general population.

## Duration and Success Rate

Costs for clinical trials can range into the billions of dollars per approved drug, and the complete trial process to approval may require 7–15 years.(no content)Only 10 percent of all drugs started in human clinical trials become approved drugs.

## Regulatory Requirements

Clinical trials are conducted only after they have received health authority/ethics committee approval in the country where approval of the therapy is sought.

Links: [{"title":"Modeling and simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modeling_and_simulation"},{"title":"Society for Modeling and Simulation International - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Modeling_and_Simulation_International"},{"title":"International Journal of Modelling and Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Journal_of_Modelling_and_Simulation"},{"title":"Modeling and simulation of batch distillation unit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modeling_and_simulation_of_batch_distillation_unit"},{"title":"Modelling and Simulation in Materials Science and Engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modelling_and_Simulation_in_Materials_Science_and_Engineering"},{"title":"Simulation modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_modeling"},{"title":"Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Army Model and Simulation Office - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Army_Model_and_Simulation_Office&redirect=no"},{"title":"OpenSim (simulation toolkit) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenSim_(simulation_toolkit)"}]

Here are the key results from the web search on modeling and simulation:

## Definition

Modeling and simulation (M&S) is the use of models (e.g., physical, mathematical, behavioral, or logical representation of a system, entity, phenomenon, or process) as a basis for simulations to develop data utilized for managerial or technical decision making.

## Key Components

In the computer application of modeling and simulation a computer is used to build a mathematical model which contains key parameters of the physical model. The mathematical model represents the physical model in virtual form, and conditions are applied that set up the experiment of interest. The simulation starts – i.e., the computer calculates the results of those conditions on the mathematical model – and outputs results in a format that is either machine- or human-readable.

## Benefits

M&S helps to reduce costs, increase the quality of products and systems, and document and archive lessons learned. Additionally, the use of such mathematical models and simulations avoids actual experimentation, which can be costly and time-consuming.

## Applications

Simulation is used in many contexts, such as simulation of technology for performance tuning or optimizing, safety engineering, testing, training, education, and video games.

## Distinction Between Modeling and Simulation

Although the terms "modeling" and "simulation" are often used as synonyms within disciplines applying M&S exclusively as a tool, within the discipline of M&S both are treated as individual and equally important concepts. Modeling is understood as the purposeful abstraction of reality, resulting in the formal specification of a conceptualization and underlying assumptions and constraints. The execution of a model over time is understood as the simulation.
